raw_text:
House prices show slight increase
 
 Prices of homes in the UK rose a seasonally adjusted 0.5% in February, says the Nationwide building society.
 
 The figure means the annual rate of increase in the UK is down to 10.2%, the lowest rate since June 2001. The annual rate has halved since August last year, as interest rises have cooled the housing market. At the same time, the number of mortgage approvals fell in January to a near 10-year low, official Bank of England figures have shown.
 
 Nationwide said that in January house prices went up by 0.4% on the month and by 12.6% on a year earlier. "We are not seeing the market collapsing in the way some had feared," said Nationwide economist Alex Bannister. There have been a number of warnings that the UK housing market may be heading for a downturn after four years of strong growth to 2004. In November, Barclays, which owns former building society the Woolwich, forecast an 8% fall in property prices in 2005, followed by further declines in 2006 and 2007. And last summer, economists at PricewaterhouseCoopers (PWC) warned house prices were overvalued and could fall by between 10% and 15% by 2009.
 
 The price of an average UK property now stands at £152,879. Homeowners now expect house prices to rise by 1% over the next six months, Mr Bannister said. He said if the growth continued at this level then the Bank of England may increase interest rates from their current 4.75%.
 
 "I think the key is what the Bank expects to happen to the housing market. We always thought we would see a small rise, they thought they would see a small decline." House prices have risen 0.9% this year, Nationwide said, and if this pace of increase persists, prices would rise by just under 6% in the year to December. This is slightly above the 0-5% range Nationwide predicts.
 
 Further evidence of a slowdown in the housing market emerged from Bank of England lending figures released on Tuesday. New mortgage loans in January fell to 79,000 from 82,000 in December, the bank said. The past few months have seen approvals fall to levels last seen in 1995. The Bank revealed that 48,000 fewer mortgages were approved in January than for the same month in 2004. Overall, mortgage lending rose by £7.2bn in January, marginally up on the £7.1bn rise in December.
llama3.2:1b: House prices increased by 0.4% in February and 12.6% from a year earlier at Nationwide building society.
The annual rate of increase has halved since August last year due to rising interest rates cooling the housing market.
Mortgage approvals fell in January to a near 10-year low, while house price growth slowed to 1% over the next six months.
If current trends persist, Nationwide economist Alex Bannister predicts an 8-15% decline in property prices by 2009.
llama3.2:3b: UK house prices rose 0.5% seasonally adjusted in February, with an annual rate of increase of 10.2%, down from 21.6% in August last year.
The number of mortgage approvals fell to a near 10-year low in January.
Homeowners expect a 1% rise in prices over the next six months.
gemma2:2b: UK house prices increased by 0.5% in February, bringing the annual growth rate down to 10.2%.
This is the lowest rate since June 2001 and a significant decline from August last year when interest rates cooled the market.
Mortgage approvals fell to near-decade lows in January.
While some predicted a housing market crash, Nationwide economists remain optimistic with predictions of continued modest growth and minimal price drops.
Overall, house prices are valued at £152,879 and homeowners expect further modest increases.
Mortgage lending figures also indicate a slowdown in the market as approvals fell to levels last seen in 1995.
qwen2.5:0.5b: House prices in the UK rose at a seasonally adjusted rate of 0.5%, according to Nationwide building society data released February.
The annual rate of increase has been down to 10.2% since June 2001, with rates falling sharply in August and January this year.
Homeowners expect house prices to rise by 1% over the next six months, with the Bank of England anticipating interest rates to rise from their current level of 4.75%.
Mortgage approvals fell to a near-20-year low in January and new mortgage loans were approved by only 8,200 units compared to December's 182,000.
The Bank of England revealed that mortgage lending rose by £7.2 billion in January but this was marginally up on the previous month.
qwen2.5:1.5b: House prices in the UK increased slightly in February compared to a seasonally adjusted 0.5% increase year-over-year.
However, this represents the lowest annual rate since June 2001 and is down from an earlier high of 8% in August 2004.
This slowdown coincides with a decrease in mortgage approvals.
House prices have risen by 0.9% for the year to date, and if this trend continues, they would increase by just over 6% over the next six months.
Additionally, Bank of England lending figures show that mortgage applications fell significantly compared to previous years, indicating further cooling in the housing market.
qwen2.5:3b: House prices in the UK increased slightly by 0.5% seasonally in February, bringing the annual rate of increase to 10.2%, down from its peak of nearly 21% in 2004.
Despite this slight uptick, mortgage approvals fell to near a 10-year low and have halved since August due to rising interest rates.

Nationwide suggests that while there are concerns about a housing market downturn, recent increases suggest prices may only rise slightly further over the next six months, possibly leading to interest rate hikes from the Bank of England.
New mortgage loans in January declined by 3,000 compared to December.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: The UK house prices showed a seasonally adjusted increase of 0.5% in February, marking a notable upward trend for the annual rate at 10.2%.
This decline from June 2001 to now is due to interest rates increasing and cooling the market.

tinyllama:1.1b: As per Nationwide's latest house price data, prices have slightly slipped downwards with a seasonal adjusted increase of 0.5%.
The annual rate of growth has halved since August last year, and the Bank of England is now forecasting further declines in property values over the next six months.
House prices now stand at an average value of £152,879, but if interest rates continue to rise, prices are expected to rise by 6% for the entire year to December.
However, further evidence of a slowdown in the housing market has emerged from recent bank data released on the same day.
New mortgage loan approvals fell to 79,000 in January, compared to 82,000 in December, while the Bank of England revealed that overall mortgage lending rose by £7.2bn in January.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In summary, Britain's housing market saw a slight increase in prices in February, but there is concern about its stability.
The Nationwide building society forecasts the market will decline by approximately 10% to 15% by 2009.
The Bank of England has raised their expectation for home price growth from 4.75% to a potential increase of up to 6%.
If this pace continues, house prices may rise by 6% in the year to December.
phi:2.7b: House prices in the UK rose 0.5% seasonally adjusted in February, but at a slower annual rate of 10.2%, marking the lowest increase since 2001.
The decrease in house price growth is attributed to interest rate increases and fewer mortgage approvals.
In January, house prices increased by 0.4% month-on-month and 12.6% year-on-year.

Despite this slowdown, homeowners are still expecting a 1% price rise over the next six months, with the possibility of an increase in interest rates if the housing market continues to grow at its current pace.
The Bank of England is closely monitoring the situation.

This is the lowest rate since June 2001, and the annual rate has halved since August last year due to interest rises cooling the housing market.
Homeowners now expect house prices to rise by 1% over the next six months, and if this pace of increase persists, prices will rise by just under 6% in the year to December.

However, there are further signs of a slowdown in the housing market with Bank of England lending figures revealing approvals fell to 79,000 in January from 82,000 in December, and mortgage lending rose by £7.2bn in January marginally up on the £7.1bn rise in December.
hermes3:3b: UK house prices slightly increased by 0.5% in February, dropping to an annual rate of 10.2%.
Despite slight increase, housing market is cooling as mortgage approvals fall to a near 10-year low and homeowners expect price growth to remain stable over next six months.

This decrease in interest rates has caused a fall in mortgage approvals to near 10-year lows.

chatgpt-4o-latest: House prices in the UK rose by 0.5% in February, with the annual increase slowing to 10.2%, the lowest since June 2001.
Rising interest rates have cooled the market, and mortgage approvals in January fell to a near 10-year low.
Despite concerns of a downturn, Nationwide economist Alex Bannister stated the market is not collapsing.
Forecasts predict potential price declines in the coming years.
The average UK home now costs £152,879, and homeowners expect a 1% rise in prices over the next six months.
If current trends continue, house prices could rise by nearly 6% by December.
Bank of England data shows mortgage approvals have dropped significantly, with lending increasing slightly in January.
stablelm2:1.6b: House prices in the UK saw a slight increase of 0.5% in February, despite interest rates cooling the housing market and an annual rate of increase dropping to its lowest since June.
The number of mortgage approvals fell but house prices rose by 0.4% on the month and by 2.6% year-on-year.
Analysts had previously warned that the UK housing market could be heading for a downturn due to overvaluation or potential falls.
House prices currently stand at £1,500,0 Pounds.
If the growth continues at this level, the Bank of England may increase interest rates.
granite3.1-dense:2b: UK house prices increased slightly by 0.5% in February (seasonally adjusted), marking the lowest annual rate since June 2001 at 10.2%.
In January, house prices rose by 0.4% monthly and 12.6% year-over-year.
Nationwide's economist, Alex Bannister, noted that the market is not collapsing as feared, despite warnings of a downturn following four years of strong growth.
Homeowners predict a 1% rise in prices over the next six months if current trends continue.
The Bank of England may raise interest rates if this growth persists, anticipating a smaller increase than expected by Nationwide.
New mortgage approvals dropped to their lowest level in nearly 20 years in January, with 79,000 fewer approvals compared to the same month in 2004.
Overall, mortgage lending slightly increased to £7.2 billion in January, up from December's £7.1 billion.
If this pace of increase continues, house prices are expected to rise by nearly 6% by December 2005, above the predicted 0-5% range.
